title: Uber to lay off 14% of staff as ridership declines due to COVID-19
description:
Uber Technologies Inc. announced in a Wednesday filing that it plans to lay off 3,700 full-time employees in customer-support and recruiting roles as the company deals with a steep drop off in rides volume due to COVID-19 and proceeds with its hiring freeze. The layoffs represent about 14% of Uber's 26,900 employees that it disclosed in its latest 10-K filing in March. Uber expects to incur about $20 million in costs related to severance and other termination benefits. Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi plans to forego his base salary for the rest of the year, according to the release. His base salary of $1 million in 2019 was 2.4% of his total compensation for the year of $42.4 million. Shares are off 1.4% in premarket trading Wednesday. They've lost 24% over the past three months as the S&P 500 has declined 14%.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.

title: California sues Uber, Lyft for misclassifying drivers as independent contractors
description:
California and its biggest cities are suing ride-hailing giants Uber Technologies Inc. and Lyft Inc. for misclassifying their drivers as independent contractors instead of employees in violation of the law, officials said in a statement Tuesday. An Uber spokesperson said the company will "contest this action in court, while at the same time pushing to raise the standard of independent work for drivers in California, including with guaranteed minimum earnings and new benefits." A Lyft spokesperson added, "We are looking forward to working with the Attorney General and mayors across the state to bring all the benefits of California's innovation economy to as many workers as possible, especially during this time when the creation of good jobs with access to affordable healthcare and other benefits is more important than ever." California is suing the companies under authority granted by a new state law and under the California Competition Law. Uber and Lyft, which report financial results this week, are in the midst of undergoing big layoffs because of a downturn in the business due to the coronavirus pandemic.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.

title: Uber reportedly may cut around 20% of workforce; CTO resigns
description:
The chief technology officer of Uber Technologies Inc. is resigning, amid a report that the ride-hailing company is discussing plans to cut about 20% of its workforce. The departure of CTO Thuan Pham was disclosed Tuesday in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, which said his last day will be May 16. Pham has been with Uber since 2013 and is its longest-serving executive, according to The Information, which also reported the potential layoffs. The Information reported that Uber could cut more than 5,400 jobs due to a sharp drop in ridership during the coronavirus pandemic, including about 800 engineering jobs. Earlier this month, Uber withdrew its annual guidance and warned that its net losses would widen. Uber shares are down about 19% in the past three months, but are still up 1.2% year to date, compared to the S&P 500's 11% decline.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
